words.explanation: Refers to a male person or entity; in this context, it is referring to the king or God as the one taking action.
Past tense of 'to send'; indicates the action of dispatching or sending someone or something from one place to another.
A preposition that can mean 'out of', 'from', indicating the direction from which something is sent.
Possessive pronoun 'his', referring back to the subject of the sentence, indicating ownership or belonging.
Servants or slaves; in this context, it refers to those who are sent out by the king or God to perform a task.
A preposition used here to indicate purpose, 'in order to' call or invite.
An infinitive marker in Norwegian, used here before the verb 'kalle' to form the infinitive 'to call'.
To call or to invite; in this context, it refers to the act of inviting guests to a wedding.
The definite article 'the' combined with a participle meaning 'those who have been called or invited'; referring to the guests invited to the wedding.
Derived from 'de' above, specifically emphasizing that these individuals were invited.
A preposition meaning 'to' or 'into', indicating direction towards the wedding in this context.
The wedding; refers to the marriage ceremony or celebration to which the guests are being invited.
A conjunction meaning 'but', used to introduce a contrast or exception to what has been previously stated.
The definite article 'the', used here to refer back to the previously mentioned invited guests.
Past tense of 'to want' or 'to wish'; indicates the guests' refusal or unwillingness to come.
A negation word meaning 'not', used here to indicate the refusal of the invited guests.
To come; in this context, it refers to the act of attending or going to the wedding.
